remixed_from.author: allon
remixed_from.title: A simple extender to lower a hot end, specifically the E3D v6. This may work with other extruders with a little customization.

description.text:
I remixed the original file to accommodate M3 screws rather than M2.5, and I also made the extension taller. I am currently using this on my Printrbot Plus 1404 for any interested. 06/03/15:
There are now 4 versions of this adapter to fit varying uses. I have added a version which has a slimmer notch for mounting which is more similar to the Printrbot Hotend. I also added two variants that have M3 nuts on the backside to reduce the likelihood of the two halves coming apart.

comments.text:
I've been playing with the idea of upgrading for quite some time, I think I will pull the trigger now.
Just one thing I was wondering about: How do you connect the fan? I was thinking about hard wiring it to 5V, but this would mean the fan is on, as soon as I start the machine.
comments.author: stylesuxx

comments.text: lol, i got exactly the same idea for lowering my e3d on a sparkcube, good that i searched for something similar first. nice design.
comments.author: zeus

comments.text: Thank you! Hope it was helpful to you. If you have any questions or constructive criticism, please feel free to comment back.
comments.author: zeus

comments.text: Does this adapter work with PrintrBot Simple Metal?
comments.author: ram1505

comments.text: I don't see any reason why it wouldn't. If you have trouble, let me know and maybe I can make another design to fix it.
comments.author: ram1505

comments.text: I printed this out but had to make a change. I am using this to mount an E3D V6 on my Metal Plus 1412 and it is too long and makes it so the Z probe can't be set low enough. I had to remove 5mm off the over length, works great now. Thanks
comments.author: bobh9286

comments.text: I did the same thing, although I took off 7mm and probably could have done 9mm for a better match to the original fan shroud. I just noticed, that this is a remix of a shorter version (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:749929) which is probably exactly what I needed.
comments.author: bobh9286

comments.text: The reason for this (I imagine) is that this was designed for my Plus 1404 which is made from 6mm plywood, so while I needed it to be a bit longer, you don't. That and the probe on the Metal plus is mounted really high. Is there a reason you can't just use the V6 in your extruder without an adapter? The only reason I couldn't was the aforementioned thick plywood hole that it mounts to
comments.author: bobh9286

comments.text:
The V6 is about 13mm shorter than the Ubis so it is too short for the Plus. There is a spacer / adapter that people are using and claim works for them http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:559657
My problem with using this one is that if my nozzle hits anything then it just pops out of the extruder, so I was looking for something a little more rigid.
comments.author: FooFighter94

comments.text: I have a simple Metal. Just doing a visual inspection, it would seem that the new hot end with the adaptor would be about 5-6mm  longer than the Ubis hot end. Right now I have the Printrbot fan shroud. It would seem that the air flow would be striking the metal block instead of going underneath the block and cooling the print. This is just a visual look see and not precise as I am in the middle of a print.  I am still figuring things out wrt 3D printing. Will try printing the adaptor out with PLA as it doesn't seem to shrink as much. Appreciate the discussion.
comments.author: ijourneaux

comments.text:
Hi there,
I have updated the design to account for the drooping. I just printed off this new version (with supports, mind you) in ABS and with the fan on auto-cool and it fits perfectly. As far as the Fan shroud goes for the simple metal, if you can give me a relatively precise measurement on how much lower the fan shroud needs to come down, I can try to work some kind of adapter up for you, it shouldn't take long.
Thanks again for your testing of my design!
comments.author: ijourneaux

comments.text: Just letting yo know that I printed off the new design and it seems to work when printed with ABS, 0.1mm layer thickness, 50% infill with Repetier-Host.
comments.author: FooFighter94

comments.text: That's the only difference between PB and non-PB, correct. I had a problem with mine sliding around with the larger opening. I'm glad you got it to print well, though!
comments.author: ijourneaux

comments.text: Will post again when I get the E3D mounted. I decided to modified both both UBIS and E3D hotends to use JST connectors so I can easily swap between the two.
comments.author: FooFighter94

comments.text: This seems like a great idea. I was concerned about the other E3D adaptor as the connection between the hot end and extruder is limited unless you actually attach the extension to the E3D.
comments.author: ijourneaux

comments.text: Have you tried actually screwing it together? I've printed it probably 5-6 times and the only time it wouldn't fit was when my bridges drooped too much. It is a tight fit and it won't fit on the hot end the first time just by slapping it on there. If you screw it on there it should fit. I added a bit of tolerance in the design plus I've used it with an E3D lite6 and a V6. Additionally, you WANT it to be hard to push into the extruder. My first one was loose and would slip down and screw up my Z-home.
comments.author: ijourneaux

comments.text: I agree, wrt bridges. The first couple of time, there was just too much droop. After some work configuring Repetier settings for bridges,  I am pretty comfortable that it is printing correctly.
comments.author: FooFighter94

comments.text: For whatever reason, my first one made of PLA fit much better than the subsequent ones I printed in ABS. I chalked this up to my printer and me being new to printing with ABS. I too have tried this on an E3D Lite6 because it is not yet in use and has the same dimensions as the V6.  As far as the fan shroud, I assume you mean the one for cooling prints rather than the one for cooling the hotend, as that would be unchanged. For my printer (PB+ 1404), the original fan shroud was too low and would hit the bed before the hotend would, so i was already using a different one. With this extension, the E3D becomes about as long as the standard UBIS is, so standard fan shrouds can be used. What printer do you have? Maybe I can whip something up for you.
comments.author: ijourneaux

description.text: I figured that my other magazine storage box was nice, but didn't really do my rockets magazines justice... So I came up with a new design :)

This is cut from 6mm MDF Black lines - cut
Green lines - vector engrave
Yellow lines - solid engrave Assemble and glue! All the parts are in the one file - you may need to split them up for a smaller cutting bed.

A simple broken wall for wargaming, I apologize, it really isn't that good, but I tried to create the kind of brick wall like design. See a video showing the thing in blender here:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=57y5wvKb4B8 WARNING
This is just the raw 3D model, I have not actually printed it.

This is a FPV Cam Mount designed to fit in the hexagon slots on the MHQ2 Clean Plate.
I designed it with a 10 degree tilt .
It also has a hole for a 4 inch zip tie so that you can secure it to the Clean Plate.
It was designed to fit a Sony Super HAD 11 CCD 600TVL FPV board camera (32mm x 32mm).
http://www.getfpv.com/lumenier-cs-600-super-600tvl-d-wdr-camera-no-case.html Enjoy...
I Printed this with ABS at 0.2mm Layer Height and 40% infill

title: Phone Car Dock w/ Flexible Phone Holder

description.text: This is a combination of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:48746 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:491121 where the upper bracket of the "Any Phone Car Dock" is merged with the flexible phone holder mount of the "Flexible Phone Holder". This allows the mounting/configuration for holding the phone while having an adjustable mount to hold the phone (without the need for velcro). One is set for vertical mounting, the other is set for horizontal mounting.

I used 10-32 x 1" screws and nuts with washers for mounting the holder and mounting bracket to the central arm.  
The phone holder is best printed with the mount arm pointing up. Supports are required.

remixed_from.author: TimeFramed
remixed_from.title: Ingress Pack -- iPhone 6 Plus in Otterbox Defender / Anker Astro E3 combination clip

description.text:
Clip to snap on a "lipstick" style battery (22mm diameter) to an iPhone 4 or 5 in an Otterbox Defender series case.  
It has slots on side for a "hand strap" using a velcro "cable tie" (see photos).  
For an iPhone 5, it should still be able to snap into the original Otterbox belt clip while this is snapped onto the phone.  
There are two .stl files; the "logos" one has the Ingress and Enlightened logos "embossed" on it (you can spin it around in Thingview to see them).  The other file is has no logos.

I printed using a brim (to be well anchored), and with support. The brim may not be necessary, but the support will be required. I use very short power cables -- e.g., http://amzn.com/B00NH138F8 (lightning) and http://amzn.com/B002LTIXK2 (30-pin).

Customizable Electronics to Get your 3D printed thing on the internet.  Don't waste your own time building electronic hardware.  Just play with the model and tell me what you want and I will build it for you.  You can even print out this model and see how it fits in your thing.  It basically provides electronic inputs (to receive inputs from button presses) and outputs (to driver LED's or whatever) and has a web server on a wifi chip that can connect to your wifi and like magic you are on the internet.  You can also select a sensor to add motion detection or light detection or drive a relay.  Everything is controlled over the web.  If you are interested send me a message.  My main goal is to build these for my home automation projects and I want to split the cost with other for my small runs (which can be expensive due to minimum lot charges).  This is a fairly simple model and isn't supposed to be fully representative of the final electronics but all the IO's and board dimensions are realistic.  That being said if there is some information lacking in the model shoot me a message and I will answer any question.  My plan is to do my first run at the end of May and expect the cost to be around $15-25 per board with (wifi webserver plus 1 sensor) depending on how many people I can get to sign up.

comments.text:
Whats your security model?
IoIT is the bane of infosec.
Security is not a bolt-on after the fact.
comments.author: anode505

comments.text: Thanks for your comment anode505.  I agree it's something to consider but the cost of adding security to an internet connected device directly is fairly high since extra security overhead in the data transmission implies lots more number crunching which means lots more power consumption.  One solution I am considering is creating a local server that all my internet connected sensors would report to and handle added security there before it's exposing to the outside world.  I put your concern a different way:  is the added cost of security really worth it?  If yes then do I really need to expose the data stream outside my private wifi network (wifi will have an option to stay on local wifi network only)?  If yes then be ready to pay the power company for adding the processing capability.

I made it

I needed to mount a simple 12VDC power distribution system in a project.  Home Depot had some lovely Ground Bar Kits in different sizes.  To use for the positive voltage I needed an insulating standoff.  The OpenSCAD file is parametric so you can change the config variables to different size bars with different numbers of holes.  Drop the bus bar in and then screw down the wires from the sides.

comments.text: wow. the default 10mm walls are making this waaay bigger than I'd visualized. The parametric WALL variable makes this easy to adjust. But I wanted a LOT of insulative gap since I'll have 30A of 12VDC running through this and I really wanted to avoid a frame ground short.
comments.author: tdeagan

comments.text: the space between the holes is a bit small and two of the pillars between collapsed during printing, but there doesn't have to be insulation between the wires on a power bus, so no biggie.  Reducing the diameter of the through holes slightly would alleviate this.

This is a simple, small stand for the Lumia 920 that holds the phone on its side, perfect for watching videos or video calls. I needed something light, that I can easily carry with me. New in V2
  • Slightly increased the length to provide more stability
  • Added vertical fin underneath the phone holder for increased strength

You can print either 1 or 2 stands (for more stability). 1 stand - place the phone (on its side - use the side that doesn't have buttons) so that the back rests on the support. Phone needs to be balanced on the stand, so that the stand should be roughly at it's center. 2 stands (recommended) - provides more stability. Place the phone on its side, place each stand toward phone's corners.

title: Printable SparkFun Logo
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a printable version of SparkFun Electronic's logo. There are 2 versions, one is solid and the other has a hole that allows you to place it on one of the M3 bolts heads on the front of your MakerBot. It is approximately 23mm X 35mm X 8mm (W x H x D). If you don't have any red ABS to print it in, you can color it with a red permanent marker after printing it, perhaps use theorbtwo's Marker holder [ http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5570 ] with a red marker, or just leave it in the color of your filament, the Technicolor SparkFun logo! More information about SparkFun and the usage rights of their logo can be found here: http://www.sparkfun.com/static/about NOTE: I am not an employee of SparkFun and do not own the rights to the logo design. The SparkFun Logo is a trademark of SparkFun Electronics.
Print on a DIY 3D printer and display you geek powers with great enthusiasm! Or when you hack something and attach this to it, it could mean "SparkFun Inside".

I used these kinds of switches, https://www.elfa.se/en/micro-switch-16-roller-lever-medium-change-over-co-omron-electronic-components-166-1c5/p/30069512?q=*&filter_Buyable=1&filter_Category4=Micro+Switches&filter_Category3=Microswitches+%2F+Snap-Action&page=5&origPageSize=25&simi=97.5 (part is called V-166-1C5 by Omron) or basically any 'regular sized' microswitch should work, I don't think it needs to be a roller-lever type, but the placement is definitely optimised for this type. A phone charger for your electric socket. My phone was always between my bed en matras or dangling at the USB cable. So i decided to make a case for my phone that you can attach to a electric socket. There are models on the market with a tray for your phone. But those models you can still knock your phone off the tray. This model protects your phone but still got access to the touch screen. Besides that you can manage the lengt of your cable on the back of the Phone charger/holder. This particle model is designed for the Xperia S. I have added the model files (Sketch up) so you can modify it.
Please do not remove the branding name if you modify it.

When you want to print this model, keep in mind that the best way to print it is to face the front of the model to the building plate. I've used the slicer software Cura.
Printing speed between 75-100mm/s, depending on your printer and with a infill of 100%. I used a Prusa i3. Dont forget to use support, (i would use lines), the infill for support must be between 20-25%. When you print it leave a comment.

This project is a variant of the Chronos Project. The time-lapse rail is based on an Igus WS-10-40-10 and carriage which uses polymer bearings for smooth movement. With this as the platform a stepper motor, lead-screw and anti-backlash nut (for greater accuracy) can be used to turn it into a time-lapse system. By using a lead-screw and not a belt to move the carriage means when the rail is oriented vertically, the motor doesn't need to apply much extra torque in order to move the carriage. The lead-screw locks the carriage in place whereas a belt system needs to keep the motor energised to stop the camera falling. Only a small stepper motor is needed to run the rail and the system I have made is based on the Chronos Lite. The controller is powered by an Arduino Uno with a custom shield made from the Chronos Controller's open source schematic. I tested out the circuit after soldering in a RJ45 to link up with the stepper motor and limit switches, it worked well and didn't take up much space so decided to use it in the enclosure.

• Bosses inside the enclosure allowing 3mm threaded brass inserts to be used to screw the Arduino Uno down
  • The 3mm inserts were used again in order to mount the laser cut face plate
  • Ledge allowing the laser cut acrylic to sit flush with the top of the enclosure
  • A mounting feature inside the enclosure allowing an RJ45 socket to be mounted (It is a very snug fit but can also be held in using a zip tie)
  • Features with allowed the inlay of Sugru (my favorite mouldable silicone rubber) on the corners of the box for added durability and grip
    • The time-lapse rail uses a stepper motor to move the camera which makes it unsuitable for use shooting video. To get the camera from one end to the other takes around 3 minutes. However as the Igus slider and linear bearings are very smooth, I created a clamping feature which allows the carriage to be released from the anti-backlash nut on the lead screw. This means it can be used as a manual slider very quickly just with the use of a hex key. The end plates are designed to accommodate the other RJ45, stepper motor, limit switches and bearing. They also are just wide enough that the rail is stable on a flat surface such as a bench or desk.

• Sugru has been incorporated into both the end plates for as much grip as possible!
    It's not terribly heavy either
  • Copper tape is used to connect the limit switch from the other end of the rail, much better than thick wire. 
  • Wide Feet
    • By using the wider feet it allows the rail to be used on uneven ground as it can be adjusting each of the four legs. They are easy to take on and off, they just unscrew. To get the threads in the feet heli-coils have been used with 8mm threaded bar.

When sourcing parts, Ebay is your friend, you need to search for some of the items listed here: Controller Parts
  • 2.5mm Stereo Jack Socket Panel Mount (x2)
  • Black knobs (x2)
  • Momentary buttons (x4)
  • RJ45 8 pin connector (x1)
  • Short Ethernet cable (3ft)
  • 3mm push fit threaded inserts (x8)
  • Sugru
  • M3 screws (x8)
    • Time-lapse Rail Parts
  • Igus WS-10-40-10 Rail and carriage bearings
  • 8mm lead screw 1 meter (which Igus sells: PTGSG-08x1,5-R)
  • Anti-backlash nut suitable for lead screw (which Igus sells: JSRM-AB-2220-TR8x1,5)
  • 5mm to 8mm coupling
  • Copper tape
  • Limit Switches (x2)
  • RJ45 8 pin connector (x1)
  • M8 Heli-coils for feet (x4)
  • M8 threaded bar
  • mall stepper motor 
  • 8mm bearing
  • Sugru
  • Long M6 screws
  • M8 Tap to mount wide feet
  • Tripod head bolt
  • M3 screw
  • 3mm push fit threaded insert

title: Libre Hardware Licensed Parametric Laptop Design

description.text: This is a Libre Hardware (GPLv3+) Licensed Parametric Laptop Design which may be adjusted to create anything from an 8in laptop to a 15.6in laptop. The design and instructions were previously posted on here, however it was pointed out the the company running thingiverse is Makerbot. Makerbot was a community-friendly company that, on receiving Venture Capital, abandoned and alienated absolutely everybody who had supported them, by going entirely proprietary and closed source, as well as applying for patents (on public domain and other published work) in order to increase the company's "perceived value" to satisfy the greed of their investors: [http://richrap.blogspot.co.uk/2014/05/makerbot-patents-twist-knife-on-open.html] This sort of behaviour is not something that an eco-conscious Libre Laptop can in good conscience endorse, so the instructions and files are being REMOVED, and have moved to a maker-friendly site run by a company that still works closely with the community and has open hardware and libre-licensed source for its firmware. [https://www.youmagine.com/designs/libre-hardware-licensed-parametric-laptop-design]

author: lkcl

description.text:
Decade variable resistor 0 - 9,9Mohm* in increments of 1ohm with a 3d printed enclosure using moderately cheap and easily sourceable components.  
Total cost for the parts orders looks to be just under 20€  The soldering is rather tightly packed, so proceed at your own risk.  
A note about resistor tolerances: I'm using 1% resistors. I wanted something better than the really cheap and common 5% resistors, but much better than 1% costs too much. Also, the switches themselves add resistance and some variance. The tolerances don't add like some people worry for setups like this - any resistance I can dial in will be within 1% of the number on the switches - in theory. The switches add a couple ohms (1.5ish) to the box overall, so the low values will be more imperfect than the high values. Also, it's best practice that once you tune a circuit with a box like this, you remove the box then measure the resistance instead of relying on the readout.

Parts: 10-digit decimal switches x7
Banana plug connector x2
1% resistors 1/4W 9 each of 1, 10, 100, 1k, 10k, 100k, 1M There is a simplified drawing of the switch with only 6 contacts drawn. You would measure the resistance between the common and pin 0. In this case the wiper is switched to 3 so the measurement would be 3xR. You can daisy chain these up to provide more resistance, just attach the common to pin 0 of the next decade.

Introducing the Rubik's Companion Cube. More entertaining than a regular companion cube and less dangerous to have around than Wheatley. If solving the cube frustrates you too much you can always humanely euthanize it by dropping it into a giant incinerator.  
This is just a merge of Poh's companion cube and chapulina's Rubik's cube. Thanks to both for your great designs.

Instructions are from chapulina's Rubik's cube. You will need to print.
1 core
8 corners
12 edge_outer
12 edge_inner
6 center_outer
6 center_inner
6 center_core And follow the instructions in here: thingiverse.com/thing:9913 UPDATE: It looks like the page of instructions on chapulina's website is unavailable so I am going to put some basic instructions here. I will make up some instructions with photos when I get the chance but hopefully this will be enough for anyone wanting to get started now. Note: I have been trying to make my cube a bit tighter than chapulina's one. I am currently playing around with a few things but I believe the key is the length of the center_core pieces. If you are feeling adventurous you could try sanding a bit off the small end of the center_core pieces to try to make your cube a bit tighter. Step 1: Take a center_core and place it through a center_inner so that the flared end of the center_core matches to the tapered hole in the center_inner. These parts need to be able to spin freely so give them a twist to make sure they are moving well, if they are not give them a light sand but be sure not to take off too much material as this will make the cube more loose. Step 2: We now need to cap the center_inner with a center_outer. This will make the center_core piece captive but it still needs to be able to spin. Carefully apply acetone or glue to the flat outer surface of the center_inner but don't get any on the center_core. Attach the center_outer and make sure the center_core can still spin. Step 3: Repeat steps 1 and 2 for the remaining pieces. There should be 6 of these assemblies. Step 4: Glue or acetone each edge_outer to each edge_inner. Join on the two large diagonal flat surfaces so that they form a cube. There will be 12 of these assemblies. Step 5: Glue or acetone 5 of the center assemblies from steps 1 and 2 to the core. The small end of the center_core will fit onto the square faces of the core. We want to leave one of these not attached for easier assembly. Step 6: Place the core/center assembly with the unassembled side facing up. Begin filling in the corners and the edge assemblies into the core/center assembly. If your cube is fairly tight you will need to insert them on the unassembled side of the core/center assembly and then rotate them with the center piece into position. When you get to the top layer just place the corner pieces in then put the edges between them. Step 7: You now need to glue the last center assembly onto the core. This will lock the cube together. You should be able to access the last face of the core through the middle of all the corner and edge pieces on the top of your cube. Carefully apply glue or acetone to this face without getting any on the corners or edges. Place some more glue or acetone onto the small end of the center_core and place the center assembly into the cube so that the center_core will attach to the core. Step 8: Give your cube a bit of a twist to make sure everything is working with care not to put too much force on the center/core assembly if the glue is not yet fully dried.

The PlugNLearn Sensor Hub was designed by TomLong74 to implement the Sensing Platform (http://sensingplatform.org)and to be a reference implementation for makers and educators to build upon. The PlugNLearn device provides a ready to use, open source sensor network which can be used in the classroom, laboratory, or anywhere else you might take it. The device is portable, using a lithium ion battery for power, and can receive readings from up to six discrete sensors attached via standard network cable (CAT5 + RJ45). The PlugNLearn device consists of a hub, shaped like a large RJ45 connector that has a number of actual RJ45 connectors to attach sensor nodes called â€œSenseAblesâ€
This is still evolving. Detailed instructions will be available at http://sensingplatform.org/ and https://github.com/sirwolfgang/Sensing

title: The elephant - Fan Duct & Mount for prusa i2 x-carriage

description.text:
We needed a fan mount and duct for our x-carriage that was short enough to accomodate for our j-head.
We are proud to present to you "The elephant"!

Print all three parts and assemble the structure.
For this you will need the following:
  • 1x 40mm fan (12V)
  • 4x M3x20 screws
  • 4x M3x16 screws (or alternative another 4x M3x20) - for mounting the fan
  • 1x M3x30 screw
  • 8x M3 washers
  • 9x M3 nuts
    • Printed on PLA/PHA 2.85mm Colorfabb Signal Yellow, with a 0.5mm nozzle, layer height 0.3, on a Prusa i3.

The 30mm arcade buttons in the Adafruit shop are excellent for retro game projects. They're also quite aesthetically pleasing. They feature a translucent body with a very slim micro switch, so it's great for internal lighting effects. Although they do not have LEDs built in, you can actually fit NeoPixels into the body with a 3D printed diffuser. In this tutorial you'll learn how to add NeoPixels to arcade buttons.

Full tutorial is on the Adafruit Learning System
https://learn.adafruit.com/neopixel-arcade-button

description.text:
This LED disk holds 20 LEDs and has enough room for the required resistors (10ohm) if you use a 9V battery. Need some hot glue to insulate the connections but it works great.
It does have a retaining ring in order to install flush or to better mount and 2 hols on the back side to run a string should you need to tie it to something.
the Disk diameter is 40mm and the retaining ring diameter is 48mm. It sicks out behind the retaining ring 11mm and in front of it about 5mm.
The LEDs are very close to the front of the disk so you can use most any color plastic and they will show through.

comments.text: I am very interested in making one of these, you're execution looks bang-on! I see that you have a parts list, but I am having trouble finding some of the components: namely the keyboard.  Do you have any suggestions when looking for a keyboard with the correct size PCB?
comments.author: sabont

comments.text:
Hmmm...I see your problem.
If I search for ´Star wars keyboard´on ebay I cant find anything.
But if you use ´Tastatur´ (german for keyboard) you should be lucky.
http://www.ebay.com/sch/i.html?_from=R40&_trksid=p2050601.m570.l1313.TR0.TRC0.H0.Xstar+wars+tastatur.TRS0&_nkw=star+wars+tastatur&_sacat=0
This keyboard is available in 3 designs (Darth Vader, Yoda, Darth Maul).
The company which builds them is: entryx
But as I said in the instructions, it should be no problem adapting any other PCB
...it just has to fit :P
No idea how to find out which keyboard has which PCB...you will have to open it.
Buy the cheapest one you can get and hope that you are lucky.

description.text: This is a multi-purpose mount for an iPad Mini. It works in both Landscape and Portrait modes. Primary function: Snugly fits into a cup holder on my boat (Bayliner 175), near the helm to display nautical charts / use navigation software. The internal dimensions of the cupholder are 90mm. So if you have a 90mm cup holder you're all set. :) Secondary function: Desktop holder for Video Chats, reading books, watching movies, etc. The fit is very snug. You can hold it upside down and shake it without the iPad mini coming out. The photo shows an earlier version. Since then I lowered the front and back mounts to not obscure the screen as much, and because not as much support in back is needed. I also added a round opening for the Home button or the camera. It holds an iPad Mini at a 15 degree angle. Tinkercad: https://tinkercad.com/things/gFZuRKtnMAG-ipad-mini-mount/edit Made this in a couple hours. I will so miss TinkerCAD. :...(

10% infill (very strong)
1 shell (i.e. 2 total)
0.27mm layers
